Topics: Informational Text - Craft & Structure/Integration Of Knowledge & Ideas
SubTopics: Trace and evaluate the argument and specific claims in a text, distinguishing claims that are supported by reasons and evidence from claims that are not.
Content: This question has two parts. Answer Part One and then answer Part Two.
In “Frontier Boy,” which claim about Lincoln does the author make?

A.Choice: Lincoln had a determination to succeed.

Key.Rationale: The passage gives details of how Lincoln always tried to do his best and did not give up.

B.Choice: Lincoln used his physical appearance to gain popularity.

Key.Rationale: There is no textual evidence to support this claim.

C.Choice: Lincoln achieved more in his life than his parents.

Key.Rationale: Even though the reader may draw this inference, the author does not put forth this claim in the passage.

D.Choice: Lincoln understood the importance of educating others.

Key.Rationale: Even though the reader may draw this inference, the author does not put forth this claim in the passage.

Content: Which sentences from the passage support the answer in Part One? Choose two answers.

A.Choice: “Abe's stepmother encouraged him to learn all he could.”

Key.Rationale: This option focuses on how Lincoln's stepmother supported his education and does not support the correct answer in Part One.

B.Choice: “Over the next few years, he held several jobs—clearing land, splitting logs for fence rails, running a ferry.”

Key.Rationale: This option supports the claim in Part One that Lincoln was determined to succeed.

C.Choice: “In fact, Thomas could hardly sign his name, while Nancy signed with an X.”

Key.Rationale: This option focuses on the education of Lincoln's parents and does not support the correct answer in Part One.

D.Choice: “In 1830, the Lincoln family moved west again, this time to Illinois.”

Key.Rationale: This option focuses on the fact that Lincoln moved frequently throughout his childhood and does not support the correct answer in Part One.

E.Choice: “Still, he got 277 of the 300 votes in his town, and that encouraged him to run again.”

Key.Rationale: This option supports the claim in Part One that Lincoln was determined to succeed.

SubTopics: Determine a central idea of a text and how it is conveyed through particular details; provide a summary of the text distinct from personal opinions or judgments.
Content: Which sentence from “Frontier Boy” best conveys the central idea of the passage?

A.Choice: “Abraham Lincoln's rise to the national political stage and the presidency did not come easily.”

Key.Rationale: This option represents the central idea that is supported by the entire passage: Lincoln had challenges throughout his life that he was able to overcome with hard work and dedication.

B.Choice: “An eager student, Abe often walked several miles to borrow books.”

Key.Rationale: This option shows only how as a child Lincoln worked hard to succeed, and it does not connect his childhood to his adulthood and rise to national politics; it is a minor detail from his childhood, not a central idea.

C.Choice: “He enjoyed listening to his father and other adults talk late into the night...”

Key.Rationale: This option only identifies an event from Lincoln's childhood.

D.Choice: “His campaign was severely delayed, though, when he volunteered for the state militia...”

Key.Rationale: This option is a detail that supports how Lincoln's rise in politics was temporarily stalled.

Topics: Informational Text - Craft & Structure/Integration Of Knowledge & Ideas
SubTopics: Determine an author's point of view or purpose in a text and explain how it is conveyed in the text.
Content: Which statement best describes the author's purpose in “Frontier Boy”?

A.Choice: to explain to the reader how Lincoln was educated

Key.Rationale: This option misidenitfies the author's purpose. Even though the passage does include information about how Lincoln was educated, that is not the author's purpose.

B.Choice: to persuade the reader that Lincoln was a great leader

Key.Rationale: This option misidenitfies the author's purpose. The passage does not include information about how Lincoln was a great leader.

C.Choice: to entertain the reader with stories of Lincoln's childhood

Key.Rationale: This option misidenitfies the author's purpose. The author's purpose was to provide the reader with information, not entertainment.

D.Choice: to inform the reader about Lincoln's life before the presidency

Key.Rationale: The intent of the passage is to inform the reader about Lincoln's life.

Topics: Informational Text - Craft & Structure/Integration Of Knowledge & Ideas
SubTopics: Determine how the author uses the meaning of words or phrases, including figurative, connotative, or technical meanings, in a text.
Content: Read the sentence from the text box that introduces “Abraham Lincoln Autobiography.”
:box:“Lincoln enclosed the autobiography in a letter to Fell that said, 'There is not much of it, for the reason, I suppose, that there is not much of me.' ”
What does the repetition of the phrase “not much” most reveal about Lincoln?

Key.Rationale: Lincoln's claim that “there is not much of me” encompasses more than his education.
His words indicate to the reader that he was modest and downplayed his accomplishments.

C.Choice: Lincoln's reluctance to write the piece

Key.Rationale: This option is not supported by textual evidence.

D.Choice: Lincoln's fear of disappointing a friend

Key.Rationale: This option is not supported by textual evidence.

SubTopics: Determine or clarify the meaning of unknown and multiple-meaning words and phrases based on grade 6 reading and content, choosing flexibly from a range of strategies.
Content: Which meaning of the word t͟i͟c͟k͟e͟t͟s is used in “Abraham Lincoln Autobiography”?

Key.Rationale: “Lists of candidates for nominations” is the appropriate meaning based on how the word is used in the passage.
Although this option is another correct meanings of the word, it does not make sense in the given context.
Although this option is another correct meanings of the word, it does not make sense in the given context.

D.Choice: certificates showing that fees have been paid

Key.Rationale: Although this option is another correct meanings of the word, it does not make sense in the given context.

Topics: Informational Text - Craft & Structure/Integration Of Knowledge & Ideas
SubTopics: Compare and contrast one author's presentation of events with that of another (e.g., a memoir written by and a biography on the same person).
Content: Which sentence expresses how the focus of “Frontier Boy” differs from the focus of “Abraham Lincoln Autobiography”?

A.Choice: “He lost his first election, finishing eighth among 13 candidates.”

Key.Rationale: This option focuses more on other events of his life, which are discussed in both passages.

B.Choice: “He learned quickly the hard lessons of life.”

Key.Rationale: The choice reflects the focus of the first passage: Lincoln had to overcome great personal challenges as a young person.

C.Choice: “He gave most of his earnings to his father.”

Key.Rationale: This option focuses more on other events of his life, which are discussed in both passages.

D.Choice: “He joined a debating group and, in 1831, voted for the first time.”

Key.Rationale: This option focuses more on other events of his life, which are discussed in both passages.

SubTopics: Draw evidence from literary or informational texts to support analysis, reflection, and research.
Content: The passage “Paranka's Dumplings” focuses on two cooks with different styles who work in the same kitchen. Write an essay analyzing the significance of Paranka's and Olya's different approaches to preparing dumplings. Use evidence from the passage to support your response.
Read the sentence.
:box:For my research paper, I studied the giant sculptures on exibit at the museum.
Which change would correct a spelling mistake in the sentence?

Key.Rationale: This word is spelled correctly in the given sentence.
This word is spelled correctly in the given sentence.
This word is spelled correctly in the given sentence.
The word “exibit” should be changed to “exhibit.”

SubTopics: Vary sentence patterns for meaning, reader/listener interest, and style.
Content: Read the paragraph.

:box:(1) Plants, just like animals, need certain things to stay alive. (2) Water is one thing that is needed to stay alive by both plants and animals. (3) If a plant does not have water, it will start to look droopy, and its leaves will dry up and eventually fall off the stems. (4) If the plant goes without water for too long, it will die. (5) Plants need other things too, such as air and light. (6) Most plants, but not all, also need soil. (7) Those that do not need soil can get the nutrients, or food, that they need in other ways instead.
Which revision that combines sentences 1 and 2 into one sentence best improves the style of the paragraph?

A.Choice: Plants and certain animals are the same in that they need water to stay alive.

Key.Rationale: This option is wordy and changes the meaning of the sentences.

B.Choice: By plants and animals, water is needed by both to stay alive.

Key.Rationale: The phrase “by plants and animals” is misplaced and repetitive with “by both.” A correct revision would be “Both plants and animals need water to stay alive.”

C.Choice: Water, by both plants and animals, is needed to stay alive.

Key.Rationale: This option contains a misplaced modifier; water is not “by plants and animals”; water is needed by plants and animals.

D.Choice: Plants, just like animals, need water to stay alive.

Key.Rationale: This option provides the most concise revision and adds variety to the sentence structure of the paragraph.

SubTopics: Use punctuation (e.g., commas, parentheses, dashes) to set off nonrestrictive/parenthetical elements.
Content: Read the paragraph.

:box:(1) Some people think bananas, which are available at many grocery stores, make good desserts. (2) They are healthier than many other sweet foods. (3) Many people believe, that sugary desserts should be avoided. (4) Eating fruits like bananas may be a great way to enjoy a healthy dessert.
Which revision should be made to the paragraph?

A.Choice: Remove the comma after s͟t͟o͟r͟e͟s in sentence 1.

Key.Rationale: The comma after “stores” is needed to set off the nonrestrictive phrase “which are available at many grocery stores.”

B.Choice: Add a comma after h͟e͟a͟l͟t͟h͟i͟e͟r in sentence 2.

Key.Rationale: A comma is not used within a comparison; “healthier than” does not need punctuation.

C.Choice: Remove the comma after b͟e͟l͟i͟e͟v͟e in sentence 3.

Key.Rationale: The comma should not separate the verb “believe” from its object “that.” The comma should be removed.

D.Choice: Add a comma after f͟r͟u͟i͟t͟s in sentence 4.

Key.Rationale: A comma is not used within a comparison; “fruits like” does not need punctuation.

Content: Read the paragraph.

:box:(1) Monarch butterflies, like many other animals, migrate south for the winter. (2) Butterfly lovers flocks to Michoacán, Mexico, every year to see the millions of monarchs that spend the winter there. (3) These monarchs hatched somewhere in the north the previous spring, and because monarchs have a short lifespan, no single monarch lives long enough to make the return trip. (4) That task is left to their offspring, who somehow find their way north.
Which change should be made to the paragraph to correct the error in agreement?

A.Choice: Change m͟i͟g͟r͟a͟t͟e to m͟i͟g͟r͟a͟t͟e͟s in sentence 1.

Key.Rationale: Sentence 1 already shows subject-verb agreement between “butterflies” and “migrate.”

B.Choice: Change f͟l͟o͟c͟k͟s to f͟l͟o͟c͟k in sentence 2.

Key.Rationale: “Flocks” should be changed to “flock” to show subject-verb agreement in sentence 2.

C.Choice: Change l͟i͟v͟e͟s to l͟i͟v͟e in sentence 3.

Key.Rationale: Sentence 3 already shows subject-verb agreement between “monarch” and “lives.”

D.Choice: Change f͟i͟n͟d to f͟i͟n͟d͟s in sentence 4.

Key.Rationale: entence 4 already shows subject-verb agreement between “offspring” and “find.”
